|date=January 11, 2012 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|accessdate=March 12, 2014}}</ref>}} | years_active = 1977–present | label = {{flat list| * [[Extasy Records|Extasy]] * [[Columbia Music Entertainment|Columbia]] * [[Avex Group|Avex]] * [[Warner Music|Warner]] * [[EMI Records|EMI]] * [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony]] * [[Universal Records|Universal]]<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/music/2013/01/01/golden-globes-theme-xjapan-yoshiki/1802691/ |date=January 1, 2013 |accessdate=May 21, 2013 |title=Globes theme by X-Japan's Yoshiki goes on sale Jan. 15 |author=Edna Gundersen |publisher=''[[USA Today]]''}}</ref><ref name = Discogs>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/X+Japan|title = X Japan Discography|publisher = Discogs|accessdate = September 26, 2013}}</ref>}} | associated_acts = {{flat list| * [[X Japan]] * Violet UK * [[Skin (Japanese band)|S.K.I.N.]] * [[Globe (band)|Globe]] * V2 * Dynamite * Noise}} {{infobox person | child = yes | agent = [[William Morris Endeavor]]<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.wmeentertainment.com/0/cta/music/contemporary/roster/| title=North American Contemporary Roster| publisher=William Morris Endeavor| access-date=July 31, 2015| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150803145418/http://www.wmeentertainment.com/0/cta/music/contemporary/roster/| archivedate=August 3, 2015| df=mdy-all}}</ref> }} | url = {{URL|yoshiki.net}} }}
{{nihongo|'''Yoshiki Hayashi'''|林 佳樹|Hayashi Yoshiki|born November 20, 1965}}, known by the [[mononym]] '''Yoshiki''', is a Japanese musician, songwriter, composer and record producer. He is best known as co-founder of the [[visual kei]] [[Heavy metal music|heavy metal]] band [[X Japan]], for which he is the drummer, pianist and main songwriter.<ref name="eastern_standard_time">{{cite book| last=Yang| first=Jeff|author2=Can, Dina |author3=Hong, Terry | title=Eastern Standard Time| publisher=Houghton Mifflin| year=1997| location=Boston| page=264| isbn= 978-0-395-76341-4}}</ref> Yoshiki's solo career includes two [[Contemporary classical music|classical]] studio albums—''[[Eternal Melody]]'' (1993), produced by [[George Martin]], and ''[[Eternal Melody II]]'' (2005)—and the classical compilation ''[[Yoshiki Classical]]'' (2013).<ref name="noisecreep">{{cite web | url = http://noisecreep.com/x-japan-yoshiki-classical-los-angeles-2013-performance/ |title = X Japan's Yoshiki Goes Classical for Intimate Los Angeles Performance | publisher = Noise Creep | accessdate = October 24, 2013}}</ref> He has also collaborated and played with artists such as [[Tetsuya Komuro]] and [[Roger Taylor (Queen drummer)|Roger Taylor]].
In 1999, at the request of the Japanese government, he composed and performed a classical song at a celebration in honor of the tenth anniversary of Emperor [[Akihito]]'s enthronement. For the [[69th Golden Globe Awards]], the show's original musical theme was composed by Yoshiki and became available for digital download on iTunes, with all proceeds going to charity.<ref name=goldenglobes>{{cite web|url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/2013/02/yoshiki-video/|title=Yoshiki Video|publisher=Golden Globes|accessdate=November 21, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131020122919/http://www.goldenglobes.org/2013/02/yoshiki-video/|archivedate=October 20, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=huffington>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/01/11/golden-globes-opening-song-yoshiki_n_2454802.html|title=Golden Globes Opening Song Explained By Yoshiki, The Japanese Superstar Who Wrote It|newspaper=Huffington Post|accessdate=November 21, 2013|date=2013-01-11|last1=Rao|first1=Mallika}}</ref>
== Early life == Yoshiki was born on November 20, 1965 in [[Tateyama, Chiba|Tateyama]], [[Chiba Prefecture]], Japan, as the elder of two brothers in a musically oriented family. His father was a tap dancer and jazz pianist, his mother played the [[shamisen]], while his aunt played the [[Koto (instrument)|koto]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tokyojournal.com/sections/features-reviews/item/332-yoshiki.html|title=Japan's Rock Legend Yoshiki Rocks Classical Charts Worldwide|date=December 9, 2013|publisher=Tokyo Journal|accessdate=April 5, 2017}}</ref> He began taking piano lessons and music theory at age four.<ref name="Keyboard Magazine">{{cite journal| date=January 2003| title=表紙／巻頭インタビュー YOSHIKI ピアノ、クラシック音楽、これからの活動について大いに語る！| journal=Keyboard Magazine Japan| volume=1| language=Japanese}}</ref> He then became interested in classical works by [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] and [[Franz Schubert]].<ref name="Keyboard Magazine"/> In [[Elementary schools in Japan|elementary school]], he played the [[trumpet]] in the brass band, and around age ten started composing songs for piano.<ref name="Keyboard Magazine"/> This period was a decisive point in his life. He was 11 years old when his father committed suicide; he found relief in [[rock music]].<ref>{{cite news| last=Dawes| first=Laina| title=Metal Legend Yoshiki of X Japan Gets His Ovation at the Grammys| work=[[MTV|MTV Iggy]]| date=February 13, 2014 | url=http://www.mtviggy.com/articles/metal-legend-yoshiki-of-x-japan-gets-his-ovation-at-the-grammys/| accessdate=May 23, 2014|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140523045425/http://www.mtviggy.com/articles/metal-legend-yoshiki-of-x-japan-gets-his-ovation-at-the-grammys/|archivedate=May 23, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/10/25/rock-star-yoshiki-hayashi-on-how-his-career-saved-his-life.html|title=Rock star Yoshiki on how his career saved his life|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=March 30, 2017|date=October 25, 2016}}</ref> After discovering the music of American hard rock band [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], he started learning to play drums and guitar. Yoshiki was also influenced by works from [[Led Zeppelin]], [[Iron Maiden]], [[Sex Pistols]], [[David Bowie]], [[Queen (band)|Queen]], [[The Beatles]], [[Charged GBH]] and [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Sharma|first=Amit|url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/x-japans-yoshiki-the-10-records-that-changed-my-life|title=X Japan's Yoshiki: the 10 records that changed my life|publisher=[[MusicRadar]]|date=March 7, 2017|accessdate=March 7, 2017}}</ref> Soon with his childhood friend [[Toshi (musician)|Toshi]] formed a band called Dynamite in 1977. Dynamite changed its name to Noise a year later.
=== 1982–1997: X Japan === {{Main|X Japan}}
When Noise disbanded in 1982, Yoshiki and Toshi formed a new band, which they named X while they tried to think of another name, but the name stuck. In 1986, Yoshiki founded his own [[independent record label]], [[Extasy Records]], in order to distribute the band's music.<ref name="AMG">Seida, Linda.[{{Allmusic| id=p320432| pure_url=yes}} "X-Japan > Biography"]. [[Allmusic]]. Retrieved January 20, 2007.</ref> On December 26, 1987, the band participated in an [[Audition (performing arts)|audition]] held by [[Sony Music Entertainment Japan|CBS/Sony]] which led to a recording contract in August of the following year. The band's breakthrough came in 1989 with the release of their second, and major debut, album ''[[Blue Blood (X Japan album)|Blue Blood]]'', which reached number six on the [[Oricon]] chart and charted for more than 100 weeks.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.oricon.co.jp/search/result.php?kbn=ja&types=rnk&year=1989&month=5&week=1&submit5.x=20&submit5.y=7| title = Oricon Weekly Album Chart for the first week of May 1989| work = oricon.co.jp| publisher = [[Oricon]]| accessdate = January 9, 2012| language = Japanese| archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130218160521/http://www.oricon.co.jp/search/result.php?kbn=ja&types=rnk&year=1989&month=5&week=1&submit5.x=20&submit5.y=7| archivedate = February 18, 2013| deadurl = yes| df = mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/rankmusic/42172/| title = X、初期のリマスター再発商品2作が好調！| date = February 14, 2007 | work = oricon.co.jp| publisher = [[Oricon]] | accessdate = July 23, 2009| language = Japanese}}</ref> In 1990, the band received the "Grand Prix New Artist of the Year" award at the 4th [[Japan Gold Disc Award]]s.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.golddisc.jp/award/04/index.html| title=The Japan Gold Disc Award 1990| work=golddisc.jp| accessdate=January 8, 2012| language=Japanese}}</ref> In 1991 they released their hit million-selling album ''[[Jealousy (X Japan album)|Jealousy]]'', and were the first Japanese metal band to perform in Japan's largest indoor concert venue, the [[Tokyo Dome]]. The following year they announced the renaming of the band to X Japan in order to launch an international career with an American album release, however, this ultimately did not happen.
=== 1991–1999: Solo work and ''Eternal Melody'' === That same year he began his first solo activities outside X. Collaborating with [[Tetsuya Komuro]] for the rock unit V2, with a concert on December 5 at the [[Tokyo Bay NK Hall]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rakuma.rakuten.co.jp/item/f1864587897101989784|title=送料無料 未DVD化 LIVE ビデオ 小室哲哉 YOSHIKI TMN X|publisher=Rakuten|accessdate=April 2, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://japan.techinsight.jp/2015/09/tk-yoshiki-mstafes-offshot-23.html |title=YOSHIKIが小室哲哉と再会。V2のショットに「何を話してるの？」と興味津々。|date=September 25, 2015|publisher=Techinsight|language=Japanese|accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref> and the single "Haitoku no Hitomi ~Eyes of Venus~/Virginity" (背徳の瞳〜Eyes of Venus〜) in January 1992, which reached number two on the chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/108057/1/ |title=「背徳の瞳」リリース情報|publisher= ORICON STYLE|accessdate= July 23, 2012|archiveurl=https://archive.fo/20130501032121/http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/108057/1/|archivedate=May 1, 2013|language=Japanese}}</ref> On December 12, Yoshiki released his first album, the classical compilation ''Yoshiki Selection'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/prof/artist/52036/products/music/231635/1/ |title=YOSHIKI SELECTION / YOSHIKI（エックス）が愛したクラシック|publisher= ORICON STYLE|accessdate=April 3, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref> which includes classical works, and its sequel followed six years later.
In 1992, he bought a recording studio complex in [[North Hollywood, Los Angeles|North Hollywood]], [[California]], [[United States|US]]. [[Extasy Records#Extasy Recording Studios|Extasy Recording Studios]] would become where recordings for nearly all his projects take place, until he sold it in the 2010s.<ref name="Billboard November 27, 1999, p. 52">{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=gggEAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA72&dq=billboard+1999#v=onepage&q=yoshiki&f=false|title=Ainlay Installs Nashville's First SSL Axiom-MT at Backstage|journal=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date= November 27, 1999|page=52|issn=0006-2510|issue=48|volume=111|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref><ref name="teamrock" /> In the early 1990s through his record label would debut million-selling bands [[Glay]] and [[Luna Sea]]. He began learning about [[jazz improvisation]] and [[orchestration]].<ref name="Keyboard Magazine"/>
{{listen| filename=Yoshiki - Amethyst.ogg| title="Amethyst"| description=A music composition from ''[[Eternal Melody]]''.}} On April 21, 1993 he released his first original solo album, the [[20th-century classical music|classical]] studio album ''[[Eternal Melody]]'', which was performed by the [[London Philharmonic Orchestra]] and produced by [[the Beatles]] producer [[George Martin]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D00EFD7103DF93BA25755C0A96E958260&sec=&spon=&pagewanted=all| title=THE POP LIFE; End of a Life, End of an Era| date=June 18, 1998| first=Neil| last=Strauss| work=nytimes.com| publisher=The New York Times Company}}</ref> Besides including orchestral arrangements of X Japan songs, it contained two new songs as well. The album reached number 6 on the charts.<ref name="Eternal Melody ori">{{cite web| url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/music/release/d/268546/1/| title=Yoshiki Presents~Eternal Melody| publisher=[[Oricon]]| accessdate=January 2, 2012| language=Japanese}}</ref> On November 3, the singles "Amethyst" and "Ima wo Dakishimete" (今を抱きしめて) were released and reached number five and three respectively on the charts.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.oricon.co.jp/search/result.php?kbn=js&types=rnk&year=1993&month=11&week=3&submit4.x=18&submit4.y=6| title = 1993年11月第3週の邦楽シングルランキング情報 Oricon weekly single chart for the third week of November 1993| work = oricon.co.jp| publisher = Oricon| accessdate = January 14, 2012| language = Japanese| archiveurl = https://archive.is/20130218175218/http://www.oricon.co.jp/search/result.php?kbn=js&types=rnk&year=1993&month=11&week=3&submit4.x=18&submit4.y=6| archivedate = February 18, 2013| deadurl = yes| df = mdy-all}}</ref> The later single was a karaoke adaptation of the second orchestral song from the first single, but name credit went to [[Tokyo Broadcasting System Television|TBS]] as it was the theme song to one of their dramas, recorded by the lead actors under the group name NOA.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000128815|title=YOSHIKI、「薔薇のように咲いて 桜のように散って」を語る|date=July 10, 2016|accessdate=April 2, 2017|publisher=Barks|language=Japanese}}</ref><ref>{{cite books|chapter=Complete Love|title=The Dorama Encyclopedia: A Guide to Japanese TV Drama Since 1953|author=Jonathan Clements, Motoko Tamamuro|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LzeSd4SvU7cC&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=NOA+sendo+atsuko&source=bl&ots=PaspkfXiVZ&sig=UQFzJ_OWhV1Pyvkt9QRAs_5_7gM&hl=hu&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi-trC_kIjTAhVKJ8AKHWSDApkQ6AEIITAB#v=onepage&q=NOA%20sendo%20atsuko&f=false|year=2003|publisher=Stone Bridge Press|isbn=9781880656815}}</ref> In 1994, it was the 35th annual best-selling single and won the "Excellence award" at the ''36th [[Japan Record Award]]s.<ref name="noajacompa">{{cite web| url=http://www.jacompa.or.jp/recotai_his/36.html| script-title=ja:第36回日本レコード大賞| work=jacompa.or.jp| accessdate=October 20, 2012| language=Japanese| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019224105/http://www.jacompa.or.jp/recotai_his/36.html| archivedate=October 19, 2013| df=mdy-all}}</ref>
In 1994, Yoshiki worked with [[Queen (band)|Queen]] drummer [[Roger Meddows Taylor|Roger Taylor]] on a song he composed, "Foreign Sand", which Roger wrote the lyrics for. They performed the song at [[The Great Music Experience]] event in May,<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=KgHxBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA105&lpg=PA105&dq=The+Great+Music+Experience+yoshiki#v=onepage&q=The%20Great%20Music%20Experience%20yoshiki&f=false|title=The Queen Chronology: The Recording & Release History of the Band|publisher=Lulu.com|author=Patrick Lemieux, Adam Unger|pages=105|year=2013|isbn=9780991984046}}</ref> partly backed by [[Unesco]], which featured many other Japanese and Western musicians. The single was released in June, and reached the top fifteen in Japan, and 26th in the [[United Kingdom|UK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-chart/19940925/7501/|title=Official Singles Chart Top 100: 25 September 1994 - 01 October 1994 |publisher=The Official UK Charts Company |accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref> That same month, the [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] tribute album ''[[Kiss My Ass: Classic Kiss Regrooved|Kiss My Ass]]'' was released, for which Yoshiki contributed an orchestral arrangement of "[[Black Diamond (Kiss song)|Black Diamond]]" played by the [[American Symphony Orchestra]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metalexiles.com/int33.html|title=Yoshiki Hayashi - X Japan|publisher=Metal Exiles|accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.grammy.com/news/the-grammycom-interview-yoshiki|title=The GRAMMY.com Interview: Yoshiki|date=October 24, 2013|publisher=grammy.com|accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref>
With X Japan's popularity increasing, Yoshiki and the band collaborated with [[Mugen Motorsports]] and sponsored racer Katsumi Yamamoto, who drove for team "X Japan Racing" in the [[1995 Japanese Formula 3000 season|1995 season]] of [[Formula Nippon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lemans.co.jp/j_company/contents/history/|title=History|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130915034826/www.lemans.co.jp/j_company/contents/history/|archivedate=September 15, 2013|language=Japanese|publisher=lemans.co.jp}}</ref> In the [[1996 Formula Nippon season|1996 season]], they sponsored [[Ralf Schumacher]] with both him and the team winning the championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pitpass.com/55471/Vandoorne-heads-to-Super-Formula|title=Vandoorne heads to Super Formula|date=February 12, 2016|accessdate=April 2, 2017|publisher=Pitpass}}</ref> In 1997, with Toshi decision to leave the band as the success-oriented life of a rock star failed to satisfy him emotionally, the band's dissolution was officially announced in September 1997.<ref name="toshi_official_interview">{{cite web| title=Interview with Toshi| work=iyashi-no-concert.com| url=http://www.iyashi-no-concert.com/interview.html| accessdate=August 6, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215071407/http://www.iyashi-no-concert.com/interview.html| archivedate=December 15, 2007}}</ref> X Japan performed their farewell show at the Tokyo Dome on December 31, 1997 making it the last of five consecutive [[New Year's Eve]]s the group performed in that stadium.<ref name="toshi_official_interview"/> Soon afterwards, in May 1998, the band's lead guitarist [[hide (musician)|hide]] died, and Yoshiki withdrew from the public scene, as he was battling suicidal thoughts and eventually sought the help of a psychiatrist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forbesjapan.com/articles/detail/15538|title=X JAPAN・YOSHIKIが語る起業家とアーティストの共通点|publisher=Forbes Japan|accessdate=April 12, 2017|date=March 18, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref>
{{listen| filename=Yoshiki - Anniversary (Theme for the Emperor).ogg| title="Anniversary (Theme for the Emperor)"| description=Composed in honor of the tenth anniversary of Emperor [[Akihito]]'s enthronement.}} Although, he remained active as a producer, for example for the band [[Dir En Grey]],<ref name="teamrock">{{cite web|url=http://teamrock.com/feature/2014-05-10/exclusive-interview-how-j-rock-legend-yoshiki-changed-music-forever|title=EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW: How J-Rock legend Yoshiki changed music forever|date=May 10, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2017|publisher=Team Rock}}</ref> and contributed a cover song on a hide tribute album, ''[[Tribute Spirits]]''. On November 12, at the [[Tokyo Imperial Palace]] a celebration in honor of the tenth anniversary of Emperors [[Akihito]] enthronement was held and at the request of the Japanese government, Yoshiki composed and performed the song "Anniversary".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2016/11/17/music/yoshiki-prepares-classical-tour-amid-new-appreciation-legacy/|title=Yoshiki prepares for classical tour amid a new appreciation |publisher=Japan Times|date=November 17, 2016|accessdate=April 2, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/x-japans-incredible-ride-meet-rocks-most-flamboyant-survivors-20141010|title=X Japan's Incredible Ride: Meet Rock's Most Flamboyant Survivors|date=October 10, 2014|accessdate=April 2, 2017|publisher=Rolling Stone}}</ref>
=== 2000–2009: ''Eternal Melody II'', Violet UK and S.K.I.N. === In the beginning of the 21st century, he expanded his record label with sub-divisions, ''Extasy Japan'' and ''Extasy International'' in collaboration with [[Warner Music]],<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=4A8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA48&lpg=PA48&dq=Extasy+Japan+and+Extasy+International#v=onepage&q=Extasy%20Japan%20and%20Extasy%20International&f=false|journal=Billboard|title=Japan's Yoshiki Teams With Warner In Venture|pages=48|issn=0006-2510|year=2000|volume=112|issue=28|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref> and produced several artists. In 2000, he collaborated with [[7-Eleven]] on a series of TV commercials, for which he provided the songs "Blind Dance" and "The Other Side" by his solo musical project Violet UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://okmusic.jp/#!/videos/2aIaWZ5tBCY?artist_id=794|title=YOSHIKI 7- Eleven CM&MAKING①VIOLET UK|publisher=OK Music|language=Japanese|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> Two years prior, he contributed the song "Sane" for the 1998 film ''[[In God's Hands (film)|In God's Hands]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.xjapan.de/interviews/yoshikinetspecial.htm|title=Yoshikinet Special Interview|publisher=Xjapan.de|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0140282/soundtrack|title=In God's Hands Soundtrack|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> The project idea was born in 1991,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://columbia.jp/yoshiki/text1.html|title=About Violet UK|publisher=Columbia.jp|accessdate=April 4, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref> when Yoshiki was recording in his studio, initially doing sessions with [[Mick Karn]] and [[Jane Child]], but it was postponed. The music involves a fusion of [[trip rock]], [[breakbeat]], and classical piano strings.
In September 2002, he joined the dance-oriented pop group led by Tetsuya Komuro, [[Globe (band)|Globe]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.avexnet.or.jp/globe/profile.html|title=Globe profile|work=avexnet.or.jp|accessdate=April 4, 2017|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120719163625/http://www.avexnet.or.jp/globe/profile.html|archivedate=July 19, 2012|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Though his only contribution was the single "Seize the Light" and, after recording an album, they went on hiatus with Yoshiki not rejoining them afterwards. On December 3 and 4, he held [[Symphonic Concert 2002|symphonic concerts]] with the [[Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra]], at [[Tokyo International Forum]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000006070| title=YOSHIKI、本格始動の第１作目をついに発売！| date=March 9, 2005| work=barks.jp| accessdate = April 4, 2017| language=Japanese}}</ref> They performed older orchestral arrangements and songs created for Violet UK, featuring female singers Daughter and [[Nicole Scherzinger]], with Nicole singing "I'll Be Your Love". That same song was released the following year as the debut single for Dahlia, an American-Japanese female singer, and later used as the official theme song of the [[world's fair]], [[Expo 2005]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://columbia.jp/dahlia/en_index.html| title=Dahlia I'll Be Your Love/2003.10.29 Debut| work=columbia.jp| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.expo2005.or.jp/en/whatexpo/mascot.html| title=Information on the Expo 2005| work=expo2005.or.jp| publisher=Japan Association for the 2005 World Exposition|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref>
{{listen| filename=Violet UK - Mary Mona Lisa.ogg| title="Mary Mona Lisa"| description=A song by Yoshiki's musical project Violet UK.}} In 2003 and 2004, he provided the theme songs "Kimi Dake Dakara" and "Sekai no Owari no Yoru ni" for [[NHK]]'s 50th anniversary commemorative broadcast and the 90th anniversary of [[Takarazuka Revue]].<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/osaka/ente/takarazuka/backnumber/040529/takarazuka.html| title=元X-JAPANのＹＯＳＨＩＫＩが楽曲を提供 花組公演「タカラヅカ舞夢！」| work=sponichi.co.jp| publisher=Sports Nippon Newspapers| accessdate=January 8, 2012| language=Japanese| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120913033327/http://www.sponichi.co.jp/osaka/ente/takarazuka/backnumber/040529/takarazuka.html| archivedate=September 13, 2012| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://columbia.jp/yoshiki/em2shosai.html|title=YOSHIKI / ETERNAL MELODY II|publisher=columbia.jp|accessdate=April 4, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref> In 2004 he helped produce the [[South Korea]]n rock band [[The TRAX]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3028242|title=Trax makes comeback after 5 years|date=January 5, 2017|publisher=[[Korea JoongAng Daily]]|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000004312|title=YOSHIKI全面プロデュースでTRAXデビュー！|date=December 13, 2004 |accessdate=April 4, 2017|publisher=Barks|language=Japanese}}</ref> In 2005, a second classical solo album titled ''[[Eternal Melody II]]'' was released on March 23.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/ranking/4771/| title=YOSHIKI『ETERNAL MELODY II』好スタート！| date=March 23, 2005 | work=oricon.co.jp| publisher=Oricon| accessdate=January 8, 2012| language=Japanese}}</ref><ref name="Yoshiki Columbia">{{cite web | url=http://columbia.jp/yoshiki/| title=Yoshiki's Columbia website| work=columbia.jp| publisher=Columbia Music Entertainment, Inc| accessdate=January 8, 2012| language=Japanese}}</ref> The next day, Yoshiki conducted the Super World Orchestra in the opening ceremony of the World's Fair in the performance of a classical version of "I'll Be Your Love."<ref name="Golden Globes">{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/blog/2012/01/10511/ |title = Yoshiki to compose Golden Globes theme|publisher = Golden Globes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107153515/http://www.goldenglobes.org/blog/2012/01/10511/ |archivedate=January 7, 2012 |date=January 5, 2012 |accessdate=December 18, 2016}}</ref> At the end of the same month, a DVD recording of his previous symphonic concert was released.<ref name="Yoshiki Columbia"/> In December, the Violet UK song "Sex and Religion" was released via the [[iTunes Store]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/VIOLET-UK-Sex-Religion/release/4199469|title=VIOLET UK – Sex & Religion |publisher=Discogs|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> and soon afterwards "Mary Mona Lisa" unofficially via [[Myspace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://myspace.com/violetuk/music/song/mary-mona-lisa-26596168-26397353|title=Mary Mona Lisa|publisher=Violet UK Myspace|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Yoshikixjapan.jpg|thumb|left|Yoshiki at [[Otakon]] in 2006.]] In 2006, Yoshiki appeared at the [[Otakon]] convention on August 6, where it was publicly announced that he would be forming a band named [[Skin (Japanese band)|S.K.I.N.]] with rock singer [[Gackt]], soon afterwards they were joined by [[Sugizo]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/entertainment/news/2006/12/28/03.html| title=YOSHIKI&Gackt新バンドにSUGIZO加入| date=December 18, 2006 |publisher=sponichi.co.jp| language= Japanese| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070323105831/http://www.sponichi.co.jp/entertainment/news/2006/12/28/03.html| archivedate=March 23, 2007}}</ref> At the JRock Revolution Festival on May 25, 2007, which was organized by Yoshiki, it was announced that [[Miyavi]] was joining.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/confidence/44947/| title=YOSHIKI、新バンド「SKIN」今夏始動を発表！| date=May 27, 2007 |publisher=[[Oricon]]| language=Japanese}}</ref> There were high expectations for the band, like to be the first Asian band to conquer the world charts, beginning with America,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://skin-online.net/main.html| title=S.K.I.N. Online| work=SKIN-online.net| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070702160935/http://skin-online.net/main.html| archivedate=July 2, 2007}}</ref> and to lead a rock revolution and starting a new era of rock and roll, by opening the market for Japanese in the Western music industry.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.jrockrevolution.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=48&Itemid=1| title=Asian Imports: Attempting to Break Into the U.S. Music Industry| date=June 19, 2007| publisher=jrockrevolution.com| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629195732/http://www.jrockrevolution.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=48&Itemid=1| archivedate=June 29, 2007| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref> But after their debut performance on June 29, 2007 at the [[Anime Expo]] in [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]], all activities were stopped.<ref name="Anime Expo">{{Cite web|title=Anime Expo 2007 announcement: Miyavi, Gackt, Yoshiki & Sugizo band performance on 6/29/2007|publisher=Anime Expo|url=http://www.anime-expo.org/?q=story/anime_expo_2007_announces_j_rock_concert_of_the_century|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626112311/http://www.anime-expo.org/?q=story%2Fanime_expo_2007_announces_j_rock_concert_of_the_century|archivedate=June 26, 2007|accessdate=March 23, 2012|deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="JaME">{{Cite web |title= 'Super band' S.K.I.N. Confirmed |url= http://www.jame-world.com/us/news-22271--super-band-s-k-i-n-confirmed.html |publisher=JaME |date=May 26, 2007 |accessdate=March 14, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.jame-world.com/us/articles-2713-s-k-i-n-s-world-debut.html |title=S.K.I.N.'s World Debut |author=Sarah |date=July 25, 2007 |work= jame-world.com |publisher=Japanese Music Entertainment |accessdate= March 14, 2017}}</ref>
[[File:Yoshiki with drum kit 2011.jpg|thumb|Yoshiki at his drum kit during a 2011 X Japan concert in [[São Paulo]], after the band's reunion in 2007.]] That same year he co-produced the soundtrack for the 2007 film ''[[Catacombs (2007 film)|Catacombs]]'', which included the Violet UK song "Blue Butterfly" and was released by his Extasy Records International.<ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0449471/fullcredits| title=Credits for ''Catacombs''| work=imdb.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://jrockrevolution.com/jrock-revolution-at-the-catacombs-world-premiere/|title=Jrock Revolution at the Catacombs World Premiere|publisher=JRock Revolution|date=October 1, 2007|accessdate=April 4, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404221147/https://jrockrevolution.com/jrock-revolution-at-the-catacombs-world-premiere/|archivedate=April 4, 2017|df=mdy-all}}</ref> On October 22, 2007, X Japan's living members reunited and appeared together for the first time in over 10 years at a public filming of the promotion video for their new single "[[I.V. (X Japan song)|I.V.]]", which was created for the American horror movie ''[[Saw IV]]'' and played during the end credits but was not included on the soundtrack album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metalunderground.com/reviews/details.cfm?releaseid=1272|title="Saw IV: Music From and Inspired By Saw IV" (CD)|publisher=Metal Underground|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://purpleskymagazine.com/2010/06/press-release-x-japan-members-yoshiki-sugizo-to-appear-perform-at-otakon-2010/|title=[press release] X Japan Members Yoshiki & Sugizo to Appear & Perform at Otakon® 2010 |publisher=Purple Sky Magazine|accessdate=April 4, 2017|date=June 17, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title = Official announcement of X Japan's Aqua City performance| work = xjapan.ne.jp| url = http://www.xjapan.ne.jp/new_c/xjapan.jpg| language = Japanese| accessdate = October 19, 2007| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071023060918/http://www.xjapan.ne.jp/new_c/xjapan.jpg| archivedate = October 23, 2007}}</ref> On September 20, 2007, at a ''Catacombs'' preview in Japan, it was announced that Yoshiki would be producing the 2008 rock [[Musical film|musical]] ''[[Repo! The Genetic Opera]]'' and [[Repo! The Genetic Opera (soundtrack)|its soundtrack]], along with composing one extra track for it.<ref name="catacombs_preview">{{cite web| url=http://natalie.mu/news/show/id/3469| title=''Catacombs'' preview information| date=September 20, 2007| work=natalie.mu| accessdate=September 24, 2007| language=Japanese| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070925034117/http://natalie.mu/news/show/id/3469| archivedate=September 25, 2007| df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="repo_opera">{{cite news| url=http://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/prnewswire/LAM01624092007-1.htm| title=Repo! The Genetic Opera: Principal Photography Underway| work=money.cnn.com| accessdate=September 26, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012042315/http://money.cnn.com/news/newsfeeds/articles/prnewswire/LAM01624092007-1.htm <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->| archivedate=October 12, 2007}}</ref> In 2009, he contributed the theme song "Blue Sky Heaven" for the 30th anniversary of a [[Nippon Television]] program,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ntv.co.jp/zoomin/info/index_090330.html| title=「ズームイン!!SUPER」30周年記念| work=ntv.co.jp| publisher=Nippon Television Network Corporation| accessdate=January 9, 2012| language=Japanese| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029185707/http://www.ntv.co.jp/zoomin/info/index_090330.html| archivedate=October 29, 2013| df=mdy-all}}</ref> and for the Japanese historical fantasy film ''[[Goemon (film)|Goemon]]'' he wrote the Violet UK song "Rosa", which was released on April 29 via iTunes.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000049046| title=『GOEMON』映画会場で先着5万人にVIOLET UKの「ROSA」プレゼント| date=April 30, 2009 | publisher=Barks| accessdate=January 10, 2012}}</ref> That year he again collaborated with Mugen Motorsports and racing car constructor [[Dome (constructor)|Dome]] for the [[Super GT]] series [[2009 Super GT season|championship]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.japantoday.com/category/entertainment/view/yoshiki-collaborates-with-racing-team-for-2009-super-gt-series| title=YOSHIKI collaborates with racing team for 2009 Super GT series| date=February 12, 2009 | work=[[Japan Today]]| publisher=GPlusMedia Co., Ltd.| accessdate=January 9, 2012}}</ref> In July 2009, he had to undergo surgery for a slipped disc in his neck, and was told by doctors to refrain from heavy drumming.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantoday.com/category/entertainment/view/yoshiki-recovering-from-back-surgery-reveals-fans-will-benefit-in-his-will|title=YOSHIKI, recovering from back surgery, reveals fans will benefit in his will|date=August 25, 2009|accessdate=April 12, 2017|publisher=Japan Today}}</ref> His neck is so severely damaged that Yoshiki's management has said that it, "would force a professional rugby player to retire."<ref name="YoshikiSurgery">{{cite web|url=http://www.yoshiki.net/YoshikiSurgery.html|title=Announcement from Management: Emergency Surgery for Yoshiki to Take Place|publisher=Yoshiki|language=English and Japanese|date=|accessdate=May 10, 2017}}</ref>
=== 2010–2017: Solo career and ''Yoshiki Classical'' === [[File:X Japan 20100704 Japan Expo 03.jpg|thumb|Yoshiki performing at [[Japan Expo]] in 2010.]] In 2010, Yoshiki with Toshi appeared and performed at [[Japan Expo]] in Paris on July 4.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000062456| title=X JAPAN、＜JAPAN EXPO＞に登場、8000人が熱狂| date=July 5, 2012 |work=barks.jp| accessdate=January 9, 2012| language=Japanese}}</ref> In October, he fainted in his hotel room on X Japan's tour, and was subsequently diagnosed with [[hyperthyroidism]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicjapanplus.jp/news/1/5931/yoshiki-breaking-down-at-present-hotel-with-hyperthyroidism/|title=YOSHIKI Breaking Down at Present Hotel with Hyperthyroidism.|date=October 8, 2010|accessdate=April 12, 2017|publisher=Music Japan Plus}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/80834/full/|title=YOSHIKIが甲状腺疾患を公表|publisher=Oricon Style|date=October 7, 2010|language=Japanese|accessdate=April 12, 2017}}</ref> He teamed up with Toshi again on January 24–25, 2011, at the first expensive high-end dinner show for their project ToshI feat Yoshiki, where an orchestra was utilized and later a live album released of the show.<ref name="ToshixYoshiki Oricon">{{cite web| url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/music/82297/full/?from_todaysnews| title=Toshi feat Yoshiki special dinner show| date=November 22, 2010| publisher=[[Oricon]]| accessdate=March 9, 2011| language=Japanese| archivedate=February 19, 2013| archiveurl=https://archive.fo/20130219043729/http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/music/82297/full/?from_todaysnews| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="ToshixYoshiki Oricon"/><ref>{{cite news| title=X Japan's Yoshiki seeks a second coming| url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2011/12/15/culture/x-japans-yoshiki-seeks-a-second-coming/#.WOPv3zuLTIU| author=Daniel Robinson| date=December 15, 2010 |publisher=[[The Japan Times]]| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> On March 6, Yoshiki co-organized with fashion producer Jay FR (from the fashion festival "[[Tokyo Girls Collection]]") a fashion and music event "Asia Girls Explosion" at [[Yoyogi National Stadium]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://gw.tv/age/whats_en.html| title=What's AGE - Asia Girl Explosion| work=gw.tv| publisher=AGE Executive Committee| accessdate=January 11, 2012| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130418204028/http://gw.tv/age/whats_en.html| archivedate=April 18, 2013| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.oricon.co.jp/news/music/84640/full/| title=YOSHIKI、新ファッションイベント開催へ 噂のVIOLET UKも本格披露| date=February 9, 2011 | publisher=[[Oricon]]| accessdate=January 11, 2012| language=Japanese}}</ref> At the event many special guest models walked the runway, Yoshiki's own [[kimono]] line that he designed, and both X Japan and Violet UK performed.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://gw.tv/age/guest_en.html| title=Model - Asia Girl Explosion| work=gw.tv| publisher=AGE Executive Committee| accessdate=January 11, 2012| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130418203328/http://gw.tv/age/guest_en.html| archivedate=April 18, 2013| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000067878&ref=fb| title=X JAPAN、＜ASIA GIRLS EXPLOSION＞に参戦決定| date=February 22, 2011| publisher=Barks| accessdate=March 3, 2011| language=Japanese}}</ref> On May 27, "Yoshiki Radio" was launched on [[Sirius XM]]'s [[Boneyard (station)|Boneyard]] station. The hour-long program hosted by Yoshiki, aired the first Sunday of every month at 9 p.m. ET.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/x-japans-yoshiki-host-yoshiki-187516| title=X Japan's Yoshiki to Host 'Yoshiki Radio' Show on SiriusXM (Exclusive)| author=Eric Pedersen| date=May 12, 2011 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]| accessdate=May 17, 2011}}</ref> On July 21, at [[San Diego Comic-Con International]], Yoshiki unveiled the comic book series ''Blood Red Dragon'', which was done in collaboration with American comic book legends [[Stan Lee]] and [[Todd McFarlane]] and stars a [[superhero]] version of himself.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://comics.ign.com/articles/117/1179255p1.html| title=Stan Lee & Todd McFarlane Team with Music Icon| date=June 26, 2011 | work=comics.ign.com| publisher=[[IGN|IGN Entertainment]]| accessdate=July 7, 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Yoshiki at Grammy Museum 2013-08-26 09.jpg|thumb|left|Yoshiki playing the piano at [[Grammy Museum at L.A. Live|the Grammy Museum]] in 2013.]] In 2012, Yoshiki composed the theme song for the [[69th Golden Globe Awards]],<ref name="Golden Globes" /> and on January 15, 2013, the theme was officially released through iTunes in 111 countries, with all proceeds being donated to charities chosen by the [[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/2013/01/yoshikis-golden-globes-theme-to-be-released-internationally/| title=Yoshiki's Golde Globe theme to be released internationally| date=January 7, 2013 |author=AnaMaria| work=goldenglobes.org| accessdate=October 10, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130306105710/http://www.goldenglobes.org/2013/01/yoshikis-golden-globes-theme-to-be-released-internationally|archivedate=March 6, 2013}}</ref> A wax figure of Yoshiki was unveiled at [[Madame Tussauds]] Hong Kong wax museum in May 2012. In 2013, Yoshiki's figure was moved to the Tokyo location.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2013/05/21/entertainment-news/x-japan-wax-lyrical-at-madame-tussauds-debut/#.VRVqR5PF9Hh | title = X Japan waxes lyrical at Madame Tussauds debut | publisher = ''The Japan Times'' | date = May 21, 2013 | accessdate = July 31, 2015 | author = Sunda, Mike}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.revolvermag.com/news/x-japan-frontman-gets-wax-figure-at-madame-tussauds-hong-kong.html | title = X Japan Frontman Unveils Wax Figure at Madame Tussauds Hong Kong |publisher=Revolver |date=May 31, 2012 | accessdate = July 31, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://loudwire.com/x-japan-yoshiki-madame-tussauds-wax-figure/ | title = X Japan's Yoshiki Becomes a Madame Tussauds Wax Figure | publisher = Loudwire | date = May 31, 2012 | accessdate = July 31, 2015 | author = Mary Ouellette}}</ref> On August 27, 2013, the third classical studio album ''[[Yoshiki Classical]]'' was released.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/5719476/spotlight-on-yoshiki| title=Japan's Renaissance Rocker Goes 'Classical'| author=| work=billboard.com| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://www.pianistmagazine.com/news/general/composer-and-pianist-yoshiki-releases-new-cd| title=Composer and pianist Yoshiki releases new CD| date=September 26, 2013 |work=pianistmagazine.com| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> It debuted as the #1 overall classical seller in Japan, and the #2 in the United States iTunes Store chartlist.<ref name="Vents">{{cite web |url=http://ventsmagazine.com/yoshikis-important-announcement-grammy-museum-launch-world-tour/ |title=Yoshiki's important announcement at the Grammy Museum |last1=Frometa |first1=RJ |date=February 24, 2014 |publisher=ventsmagazine.com |accessdate=March 12, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150523055215/http://ventsmagazine.com/yoshikis-important-announcement-grammy-museum-launch-world-tour/|archivedate=May 23, 2015}}</ref> In celebration of its release, a special live performance was held at [[Grammy Museum at L.A. Live|the Grammy Museum]].<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.grammymuseum.org/events/detail/the-drop-yoshiki| title=The Drop: Yoshiki| author=| work=billboard.com| accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://noisecreep.com/x-japan-yoshiki-classical-los-angeles-2013-performance/?trackback=fbshare_top| title=X Japan's Yoshiki Goes Classical for Intimate Los Angeles Performance| date=August 27, 2013 | author=Corey Irwin| work=noisecreep.com| accessdate=October 10, 2013}}</ref><ref name = huffingtonpostvideo>{{cite web| url=https://www.aol.com/video/view/yoshiki-releases-new-classical-album/5544dedde4b042cdf606c370/| title=Yoshiki Releases New Classical Album| publisher=Reuters| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref>
On March 14, 2014, at the [[South by Southwest]] festival in Austin, Texas, Yoshiki performed a duet piano piece during his concert at the Qui Restaurant; one part played by him, and the other played by a hologram of himself.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2586429/Duelling-pianos-youve-never-seen-Musician-plays-hologram-version-HIMSELF.html |title=Musician performs with a hologram version of himself |last1=Prigg |first1=Mark |date=March 21, 2014 |publisher=dailymail.co.uk |accessdate=April 26, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://gizmodo.com/watch-a-japanese-pianist-battle-a-holographic-version-o-1548686346 |title=Watch a Japanese Pianist Battle a Holographic Version of Himself |last1=Liszewski |first1=Andrew |date=March 21, 2014 |publisher=gizmodo.com |accessdate=April 26, 2014}}</ref> On April 25, Yoshiki started his first classical world tour in [[Costa Mesa, California]], and continued throughout the world, visiting [[San Francisco]], [[Mexico City]], [[Moscow]], [[Berlin]], [[Paris]], [[London]], [[Shanghai]], [[Beijing]], [[Bangkok]], [[Taipei]], [[Tokyo]] and [[Osaka]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jetwit.com/wordpress/2014/05/03/jq-magazine-concert-review-yoshiki-classical-world-tour-comes-to-san-francisco/|title=JQ Magazine: Concert Review—Yoshiki Classical World Tour Dazzles San Francisco with Surprise X Japan Guest|author=Shirong Gao|date=May 3, 2014 |publisher=JetWit.com|accessdate=September 5, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archivo.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/2014/el-auditorio-blackberry-se-llena-de-recuerdos-y-nostalgia-1007969.html|title=El Auditorio Blackberry se llena de recuerdos y nostalgia|author=Jannis Mérida|date=May 4, 2014 |publisher=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|language=Spanish|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref name="officialtour" /> The tour setup featured Yoshiki on piano, several strings as cellos and viola, and vocalist Katie Fitzgerald from Violet UK.<ref name="SFWeekly">{{cite web |url=http://archives.sfweekly.com/sanfrancisco/classical-import-how-yoshiki-went-from-stadiums-to-concert-halls/Content?oid=2949368| author=Kirsty Evans| title=Classical Import: How Yoshiki Went From Stadiums to Concert Halls| date=April 23, 2014| publisher=SF Weekly| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> Performances included classical versions of songs he composed, as well depending on the venue, some famous composers like [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky|Tchaikovsky]].<ref name="SFWeekly"/> For an upcoming Japanese 3D CG animated film ''[[Saint Seiya: Legend of Sanctuary]]'', Yoshiki contributed theme song "Hero" and it was unveiled on the tour.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-04-17/x-japan-yoshiki-performs-saint-seiya-cg-film-theme|title= X Japan's Yoshiki Performs Saint Seiya CG Film's Theme|accessdate=April 17, 2014}}</ref> In October 2014, Yoshiki performed a concert at [[Madison Square Garden]] with X Japan. It was the group's largest U.S. headlining performance.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6281554/x-japan-madison-square-garden | title = X Japan Takes Madison Square Garden By Rainstorm |work = [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] | date = October 12, 2014 | accessdate = July 31, 2015 | author = Flanagan, Andrew}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.dramafever.com/news/x-japan-prove-their-status-as-rock-royalty-at-madison-square-garden-2014/ | title = X Japan prove their status as rock royalty at Madison Square Garden 2014 | publisher = Drama Fever | date = October 16, 2014 | accessdate = July 31, 2015 | author = Vijayaraghavan, Nandita}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.vulture.com/2014/10/x-japan-comes-to-america.html | title = X Japan Plays in Front of 70,000 People at Home. Now They're Slumming It at Madison Square Garden. | publisher = Vulture | date = October 6, 2014 | accessdate = July 31, 2015 | author = Marchese, David}}</ref> In November 2014, Yoshiki debuted the official [[Hello Kitty]] theme song, "Hello Hello", at the first Hello Kitty Con.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.yahoo.com/music/bp/yoshiki-debuts-official-hello-kitty-theme-song-at-hello-kitty-con-061843229.html | title = Yoshiki Debuts Official Hello Kitty Theme Song at Hello Kitty Con | publisher = [[Yahoo!]] | date = November 1, 2014 | accessdate = January 25, 2014 | author = Parker, Lyndsey }}</ref> He was the guest of honor at [[Stan Lee]]'s [[Comikaze Expo]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-10-26/la-comikaze-to-host-x-japan-leader-yoshiki/.80099 | title = LA's Comikaze to Host X Japan Leader Yoshiki | publisher = Anime News Network | date = October 26, 2014 | accessdate = January 25, 2014 }}</ref>
[[File:Yoshiki Piano London 2015.jpg|thumb|right|Yoshiki performing in London at the Hyper Japan Festival, 2015.]] In April 2015, Yoshiki was a guest speaker and performer at the New Economy Summit (NES).<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.techinasia.com/yoshiki-x-japan-tidal/ | title = Japan's biggest rock star isn't sold on Tidal, Jay Z's music streaming service | publisher = Tech In Asia | date = April 8, 2015 | accessdate = July 31, 2015 | author = Quigley, J.T.}}</ref> In July, he performed at the Hyper Japan Festival in [[London]], together with Toshi.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tokyohive.com/article/2015/06/x-japans-yoshiki-toshi-to-perform-in-hyper-japan-festival-2015-in-london|title=X JAPAN's YOSHIKI & ToshI to perform in 'HYPER JAPAN Festival 2015' in London|date=June 27, 2015|accessdate=April 4, 2017|publisher=Tokyo Hive}}</ref> Yoshiki performed with a string quartet at the [[2016 Sundance Film Festival]]. The ''[[We Are X]]'' film, a documentary on X Japan and Yoshiki, premiered at Sundance<ref>{{cite web| title = X Japan to Premiere 'We Are X' Documentary Film At Sundance Film Festival| url = http://loudwire.com/x-japan-premiere-we-are-x-documentary-sundance-film-festival/| work = Loudwire| date = January 20, 2016 | accessdate = January 30, 2016}}</ref> and was selected for the World Cinema Documentary Competition.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jrockradio.net/2016/01/x-japan-we-are-x-documentary-film-to-make-its-world-premiere-at-2016-sundance-film-festival/|title= We Are X Documentary Film To Make Its World Premiere at 2016 Sundance Film Festival|year= 2016|publisher= J-Rock Radio|accessdate= April 25, 2016}}</ref> In November 2016, he won the ''Asia Icon Award'' at the [[Classic Rock Roll of Honour Awards]] in Tokyo.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musicman-net.com/artist/62779.html|title=YOSHIKI、「ASIAN ICON AWARD」受賞「この賞をX JAPAN、HIDE、TAIJIに捧げたい」|date=November 14, 2016|accessdate=April 4, 2017|publisher=Musicman|language=Japanese}}</ref><ref name="teamrock2">{{cite web|url=http://teamrock.com/news/2016-11-11/jeff-beck-joe-perry-and-all-star-band-triumph-at-classic-rock-awards-in-tokyo |title=Jeff Beck, Joe Perry and All-Star Band triumph at Classic Rock Awards in Tokyo|publisher=Team Rock|date=November 11, 2016|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> In 2016, he embarked on another classical world tour, with performances in Tokyo and Osaka,<ref name="barks 2016" /> and a [[Hong Kong]] show that had to be cancelled due to the promoter's mistake and rescheduled as a free concert on December 30.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jrocknews.com/2016/12/yoshiki-hong-kong-orchestra-show-cancelled-now-fans-get-free-show.html|title=The Yoshiki Classical Special Hong Kong show cancelled but now fans get a free show|publisher=Jrock News|accessdate=April 4, 2017|date=2016-12-30}}</ref>
Yoshiki's second solo classical tour commenced in [[Osaka Castle Hall]] on December 5, 2016 with three days at the [[Tokyo International Forum]] on December 6, 7 and 8, a performance at Hong Kong's [[AsiaWorld-Expo]] scheduled for December 29 and [[Carnegie Hall]], New York on Jan 12 and 13. The Carnegie Hall performances included the [[Tokyo Philharmonic Orchestra]]. The Tokyo concerts in December were an acclaimed success<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2016/12/09/music/review-yoshiki-tokyo-international-forum/#.WNcKjPl97IU|title=Review: Yoshiki at Tokyo International Forum|date=2016-12-09}} Ryotaro Aoki, Japan Times. December 9, 2016. Retrieved March 26, 2017</ref> but the Hong Kong Concert on December 29 had to be canceled two hours before the show. The cancellation was due to an oversight by the promoter in applying for the entertainment license necessary to perform the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jame-world.com/us/news-123998-yoshiki-classical-special-in-hong-kong-cancelled-free-concert-announced.html|title=Yoshiki Classical Special in Hong Kong Cancelled, Free Concert Announced}} Silverfaye, Jame World. December 29, 2016. Retrieved March 26, 2017</ref> However the date was fulfilled on the following day, December 30, by Yoshiki performing for free with ticket holders being refunded, the first time ever for a major music artist to do such a thing in Hong Kong.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/press-release/2017-01-03/yoshiki-classical-with-orchestra-completes-hong-kong-performance-one-day-after-cancellation/.110589|title=Yoshiki plays a complimentary concert in lieu of cancellation}} Anime News Network. December 30, 2016. Retrieved March 27, 2017</ref> The concerts in Carnegie Hall on January 12 and 13 were successful sellout shows. Yoshiki also included in the show a surprise performance of ''[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]'' after a heartfelt speech about his personal pursuit of the [[American Dream]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.japantoday.com/category/entertainment/view/yoshiki-performs-2-sold-out-shows-at-new-yorks-carnegie-hall|title=Yoshiki performs 2 sold-out shows at New York's Carnegie Hall}} Japan Today. January 16, 2017. Retrieved March 27, 2017</ref>
===2017–present: Back surgery, "Red Swan" === In January 2017, he held two sold-out concerts at [[Carnegie Hall]] in [[New York City|New York]].<ref name="Japan Today 2017" /> In March 2017, Yoshiki performed with a 4-piece string quartet at Hong Kong’s Asia Film Awards. In April 2017, Yoshiki debuted a special collaboration T-Shirt with rock group KISS titled “YOSHIKISS”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2017/04/12/x-japan-and-kiss-collide-in-new-yoshikiss-shirt|title=X Japan and KISS Collide in new "YoshiKISS" Shirt}} Kara Dennison, Cruncyroll. April 13, 2017. Retrieved May 2, 2017</ref> During these performances, he lost sensation in his left hand and was rediagnosed with cervical foraminal stenosis. In May 2017, it was announced that Yoshiki would undergo emergency cervical artificial disc replacement surgery in Los Angeles on May 16, resulting in the cancelling of his schedule for May, and future events being possibly cancelled or rescheduled based on discussions after his surgery.<ref name="YoshikiSurgery"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-05-09/x-japan-leader-yoshiki-to-undergo-surgery/.115885|title=X Japan Leader Yoshiki to Undergo Surgery|publisher=Anime News Network|date=May 9, 2017|accessdate=May 9, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-39867016|title=X Japan's Yoshiki needs urgent surgery after decades of intense drumming|publisher=BBC|date=May 10, 2017|accessdate=May 10, 2017|newspaper=BBC News}}</ref> The surgery was successful, with his surgical wound expected to take six weeks to heal, and for him to make a 90% recovery in six months. However, the recovery period for the pain in his hand is unknown.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2017-05-17/x-japan-leader-yoshiki-recovers-from-surgery/.116207|title=X Japan Leader Yoshiki Recovers From Surgery|publisher=Anime News Network|date=May 17, 2017|accessdate=May 17, 2017}}</ref>
In August 2017, Yoshiki was chosen for the cover of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue Japan]]'', as the first Japanese male to do so.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://soranews24.com/2017/08/23/x-japans-yoshiki-to-be-the-first-japanese-male-to-appear-on-the-cover-of-vogue-japan/|title=X Japan's Yoshiki to be first Japanese male to appear on cover of Vogue Japan|author=Meg Murphy|publisher=SoraNews24|date= August 26, 2017|accessdate= November 22, 2017}}</ref> In July 2017, Yoshiki performed six concerts with X Japan. He also performed a series of seven Evening with Yoshiki dinner shows in Osaka, Nagoya, and Tokyo.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://jrock247.com/2017/06/x-japan-confirms-japan-tour-changes-format-to-acoustic-special-miracle |publisher= J-Rock News, Visual Kei |date= July 10, 2017 |accessdate= December 5, 2017 |title= X Japan confirms Japan tour, changes format to "Acoustic Special Miracle"}}</ref> In October 2017, Yoshiki completed a 10-country tour of Europe promoting the documentary ''[[We Are X]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://jrock247.com/2017/10/yoshiki-returns-to-paris-to-complete-whirlwind-european-promotion-tour/|title=Yoshiki returns to Paris to complete whirlwind European promotion tour|publisher=JRock News|date= October 27, 2017|accessdate= December 13, 2017}}</ref>
In 2018, Yoshiki released a song titled "[[Red Swan (song)|Red Swan]]" featuring [[Hyde (musician)|Hyde]], which is the opening theme song of the third season of the ''[[Attack on Titan]]'' anime.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000159823|title=YOSHIKI feat.HYDE、「Red Swan」は「Rusty Nail」を一部意識|date=2018-09-17|publisher=Barks|accessdate=2018-09-19|language=Japanese}}</ref> In September, it was announced that Yoshiki would feature on [[Sarah Brightman]]'s album ''[[Hymn (Sarah Brightman album)|Hymn]]'', with a newly recorded version of his composition "Miracle".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/8475396/sarah-brightman-hymn-tour-dates|title=Sarah Brightman Announces Uplifting New Album 'Hymn,' Tour Dates|date=2018-09-17|publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|accessdate=2018-09-19|language=English}}</ref>
== Influences == When asked what the albums were the most influential for him, Yoshiki named ''[[Alive! (Kiss album)|Alive!]]'' by [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]], ''[[Led Zeppelin IV]]'' by [[Led Zeppelin]] and ''[[Killers (Iron Maiden album)|Killers]]'' by [[Iron Maiden]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://sankei.jp.msn.com/entertainments/music/081116/msc0811160918002-n1.htm|title=ＹＯＳＨＩＫＩ、ロックに目覚めた３枚 「キッス・アライヴ！～地獄の狂獣」|date=2008-11-16|accessdate=2008-11-16|publisher=MSN Sankei News}}</ref> Yoshiki stated he loved "the punkish elements" of the albums ''[[Iron Maiden (album)|Iron Maiden]]'' and ''Killers'' by Iron Maiden<ref name="headbang09">{{cite journal |title= YOSHIKI再び！ |author= 柿沢ちづか(KAKIZAWA Chizuka) |journal= ヘドバン(Headbang) |pages=40–49 |volume= 9 |date= 2016-01-17 |language= Japanese}}</ref> and that their work got him into [[punk rock]].<ref name="rockinf_2000_11">『ロッキンf』（2000年11月号）立東社</ref><ref name="uv79">{{Cite book|language=Japanese|journal=UV|issue=Vol. 79|publisher=ソニー・マガジンズ|isbn=978-4-7897-9464-0}}</ref> He was into punk rock bands from the United Kingdom and Japan such as [[The Exploited]], [[Chaos UK]], [[Discharge (band)|Discharge]], [[GISM|G.I.S.M.]] and [[Gauze (band)|Gauze]] around 1984.<ref name="rockinf_2000_11"/> He also cited the [[Sex Pistols]], [[The Clash]] and [[Charged GBH|G.B.H.]] as his favorite bands.<ref name="headbang09"/>
Yoshiki has also named ''[[Symphony No. 8 (Schubert)|Symphony No. 8]]'' by [[Franz Schubert]] and ''[[Symphony No. 5 (Beethoven)|Symphony No. 5]]'' by [[Ludwig van Beethoven]] as influences.<ref name="grammy.com_2013-10-24">{{Cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/news/the-grammycom-interview-yoshiki|title=The GRAMMY.com Interview: Yoshiki|date=2013-10-24|accessdate=2014-11-28|publisher=GRAMMY.com}}</ref> Other than those above, his favorite classical composers included [[Johan Sebastian Bach]], [[Arnold Schoenberg]], [[Alban Berg]],<ref name="gigs_1997">『月刊ギグス』（1997年2月号）シンコーミュージック・エンタテイメント</ref> [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]], [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]], [[Sergei Rachmaninoff]] and [[Frédéric Chopin]].<ref name="grammy.com_2013-10-24"/>
He named [[John Bonham]] as his biggest drumming inspiration and cited [[Cozy Powell]] as the reason he started to play [[double bass drum]]s.<ref name="drums">{{cite web| url=http://www.musicradar.com/news/drums/yoshiki-x-japan-10-drummers-that-blew-my-mind-631353| title=Yoshiki, X Japan: 10 drummers that blew my mind| publisher=[[MusicRadar]]| date=November 30, 2015 |accessdate=January 30, 2016}}</ref> He also likes [[Peter Criss]],<ref name="drum_magazine_1991">『リズム&ドラム・マガジン』（1991年8月号）リットーミュージック</ref> [[Shuichi Murakami]], [[:ja:青山純|Jun Aoyama]] from [[T-Square (band)|T-Square]],<ref>『リズム&ドラム・マガジン』（1990年4月号）リットーミュージック</ref> and Minato Masafumi from [[Dead End (band)|Dead End]].<ref>ロッキンf 1997年7月号別冊 Rockin' Take CAFE（立東社） pp160 （ロッキンf 1989年9月号掲載分）</ref> He picked [[George Winston]], [[Keith Jarrett]], [[Vladimir Horowitz]] and Mishiba Satoshi from [[Kinniku Shōjo Tai]] as his favorite pianists.<ref name="Keyboard Magazine"/><ref name="rockinf_1989_11">『ロッキンf』（1989年11月号）立東社</ref> [[The Köln Concert]] by Keith Jarrett got him started to learn jazz theory and improvisation.<ref name="Keyboard Magazine"/> He also studied jazz piano under [[Dick Marx]] and [[Shelly Berg]].<ref name="gigs_1997"/>
== Charity work == In 1995, in response to the [[Great Hanshin earthquake|Kobe earthquake]], Yoshiki held an X Japan's [[Christmas Eve]] charity concert in [[Osaka]], and presented the certifications of new pianos to students whose schools were damaged during the earthquake.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000121969|title=【ライブレポート】X JAPAN、ライブハウスで咆哮|date=November 28, 2015|publisher=Barks|accessdate=April 4, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref>
In 2009, he invited 200 young orphans to attend two X Japan's concerts in January in [[Hong Kong]], and donated money to a charity organization for orphans.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.yoshikifoundationamerica.org/News.html| title=X Japan Hong Kong Live Invited Orphans to Attend Sold-Out Concert, Sets Up Charity to Aid Children| publisher=Yoshiki Foundation America| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> On March 29 and 31, he visited a town in the province of [[Sichuan]], [[China]], which was devastated by the [[2008 Sichuan earthquake|earthquake]] in 2008, and donated musical instruments to the schools in the area.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.yoshikifoundationamerica.org/News.html| title=Yoshiki Visited School in Sichuan, China One Year After Major Earthquake, Donates Musical Instruments| publisher=Yoshiki Foundation America| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> He again invited children from the local orphanages in [[Taipei]], [[Republic of China|Taiwan]], to be the special guests in the X Japans's concert on May 30.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.yoshikifoundationamerica.org/News.html| title=Yoshiki Invited Orphanages Throughout Taiwan to Attend The Band's Performance| publisher=Yoshiki Foundation America| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref>
In 2010, he founded Yoshiki Foundation America, a California non-profit, public benefit corporation with tax-exempt status as a section [[501(c) organization|501(c)3]].<ref name="YFA FAQ-Auction">{{cite web| url=http://www.yoshikifoundationamerica.org/?page_id=1194| title=Yoshiki Foundation America FAQ| publisher=Yoshiki Foundation America| accessdate=January 9, 2012| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130416080049/http://www.yoshikifoundationamerica.org/?page_id=1194| archivedate=April 16, 2013| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref> On July 1, the foundation hosted a free benefit fan bash for charity at [[L.A. Live|Club Nokia]], [[Los Angeles]]. Beneficiaries included the [[Grammy Foundation]], [[Make-A-Wish Foundation]], and St. Vincent [[Meals on Wheels]].<ref name="YFA FAQ-Auction"/>
In 2011, to provide aid to the victims of March 11's [[Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]], the Foundation in association with [[Yahoo! Japan]] organized the Japan Relief Fundraising Auction, and all the benefits were sent to the [[Japanese Red Cross]].<ref name="YFA FAQ-Auction"/><ref name="YFA Auction Artistdirect">{{cite web| url=http://www.artistdirect.com/entertainment-news/article/anthony-kiedis-marilyn-manson-donate-to-yoshiki-s-jrfa/8771992| title=Anthony Kiedis, Marilyn Manson Donate to Yoshiki's JRFA| author=Amy Sciarretto| date=April 13, 2011| work=artistdirect.com| publisher=Rogue Digital, LLC| accessdate=January 9, 2012| archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130117083712/http://www.artistdirect.com/entertainment-news/article/anthony-kiedis-marilyn-manson-donate-to-yoshiki-s-jrfa/8771992| archivedate=January 17, 2013| deadurl=yes| df=mdy-all}}</ref> Yoshiki auctioned one of his [[Kawai]] Crystal Grand CR-40 pianos, and with restructuring verification system by [[Yahoo! Auctions]], because offers reached high as $20 million,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Rock-Star-Yoshiki-Crystal-Piano-Japan-Relief-119270734.html| title=$20M Bid Shuts Down Yoshiki Auction| author=Olsen Ebright| date=April 19, 2011 | work=nbclosangeles.com| publisher=NBCUniversal, Inc.| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Yoshiki-Auction-Piano-Restarts-120495984.html| title=Encore: Yoshiki Piano Auction Re-Tunes| author=Olsen Ebright| date=April 25, 2011 |work=nbclosangeles.com| publisher=NBCUniversal, Inc.| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> it got sold for $134,931.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/news/local/Yoshiki-Piano-Ends-120881534.html| title=Yoshiki's Crystal Piano Nets $130K for Japan Relief| author=Olsen Ebright| date=April 28, 2011| work=nbclosangeles.com| publisher=NBCUniversal, Inc.| accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref>
In 2014, Yoshiki Foundation America partnered with the [[MusiCares|MusiCares Foundation]] in an auction for a private dinner with Yoshiki. The auction awarded the two highest bidders each with a dinner and raised $62,000 for the Grammy Foundation and MusiCares.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2014-11-21/bid-for-the-chance-to-enjoy-a-private-dinner-with-yoshiki/.81312 |title=Bid For the Chance to Enjoy A Private Dinner with Yoshiki |publisher=Anime News Network |date=November 21, 2014 |accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://themusicuniverse.com/yoshiki-awards-two-highest-bidding-fans-private-dinner-for-grammy-foundation-musicares-charitybuzz-auction/ | title = Yoshiki awards two highest bidding fans private dinner for Grammy Foundation, MusiCares CharityBuzz auction | publisher = The Music Universe | date = December 15, 2014 | accessdate = April 4, 2017}}</ref>
In 2017, Yoshiki Foundation America donated $100,000 to [[Hurricane Harvey]] relief efforts through the MusiCares Foundation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Merill|first=Phil|url=https://www.grammy.com/musicares/news/x-japans-yoshiki-donates-100000-musicares-hurricane-relief|title=X Japan's Yoshiki Donates $100,000 To MusiCares Hurricane Relief|date=October 16, 2017|website=[[Grammy.com]]|publisher=[[The Recording Academy]]|accessdate=December 15, 2017}}</ref>
== Business ventures == Yoshiki founded [[Extasy Records]] in Japan in 1986, using money he received from his mother when she sold her business.<ref name="JRR">{{cite web|title=Visual Kei and EXTASY RECORDS|url=http://jrockrevolution.com/2007/08/webzine/visual-kei-and-extasy-records-23|work=JRock Revolution|date=August 25, 2007 |accessdate=January 18, 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160128051136/http://jrockrevolution.com/2007/08/webzine/visual-kei-and-extasy-records-23|archivedate=January 28, 2016}}</ref> The labels Extasy Japan and Extasy Records International were later established around 2000.<ref>''Billboard'' July 8, 2000, p. 48</ref> Yoshiki founded the Japanese record label Platinum Records in April 1992, as an affiliate of [[PolyGram]].<ref name="Billboard November 27, 1999, p. 52"/>
He owned [[Extasy Recording Studios]], a recording studio complex in [[North Hollywood, Los Angeles]] formerly known as One On One Recording,<ref name="Billboard November 27, 1999, p. 52"/> which he bought from the previous owner Jim David in 1992 and renamed after his own record label in 1999. It was sold in 2012, and is now [[17 Hertz Studio]].<ref>[http://www.17hertz.com 17 Hertz Studio Website]</ref>
He bought Brooklyn Recording Studios, which housed the Los Angeles offices of [[Maverick (company)|Maverick Records]], in April 1998 from owners [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] and [[Freddy DeMann]]. He renamed it One on One South,<ref name="Billboard November 27, 1999, p. 52"/> before using it as the headquarters of Extasy Records International.<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://books.google.com/?id=mQ4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=%27%27Billboard%27%27+April+18,+1998#v=onepage&q=''Billboard''%20April%2018%2C%201998&f=false|title=Newsline...|journal=Billboard|year=1998|issue=16|volume=110|issn=0006-2510|pages=33|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref>
Yoshiki owns and operates another LA recording complex, which was formerly known as Larrabee East.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/5719476/spotlight-on-yoshiki| title=Spotlight On Yoshiki| publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]| date=September 23, 2013 | accessdate=January 19, 2016}}</ref>
In 2009, with California winemaker Michael Mondavi, Yoshiki branded a small line of wine titled "Y", which consists of a [[Chardonnay]] and a [[Cabernet Sauvignon]] from a 2008 vintage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/music/article/Musician-Yoshiki-s-creativity-covers-the-spectrum-5425757.php|title=Musician Yoshiki's creativity covers the spectrum|date=April 24, 2014|accessdate=April 4, 2017|publisher=sfgate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ybyyoshiki.com/|title=Y By Yoshiki|publisher=Japan Music Agency|accessdate=April 4, 2017|language=Japanese}}</ref>
Having grown up in a family that managed a kimono store,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://en.koreaportal.com/articles/2402/20151020/yoshikimono-debut-collection.htm| title=Yoshikimono Debut Collection Appears At Tokyo Fashion Week; X Japan Member Yoshiki Reveals Twist| date=October 20, 2015| publisher=Korea Portal| access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref> Yoshiki debuted a line of rock-inspired kimonos, Yoshikimono, at the Asia Girls Explosion fashion event in collaboration with [[Tokyo Girls Collection]] in 2011.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/08/AR2011030806491.html| title=Yoshiki seeks global rock glory for X Japan| date=March 8, 2011| last=Kageyama| first=Yuri| publisher=Washington Post| access-date=August 24, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2011/12/15/music/x-japans-yoshiki-seeks-a-second-coming/#.VbjqH7NVikp| title=X Japan's Yoshiki Seeks a Second Coming| date=December 15, 2011| last=Robson| first=Daniel| publisher=Japan Times| access-date=August 24, 2015}}</ref> The collection debuted its first fashion show during the finale of the 2015 Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week in Tokyo.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://ventsmagazine.com/2015/10/16/yoshiki-to-unveil-yoshikimono-first-collection-at-mercedes-benz-fashion-week%e2%80%8f/| title=Yoshiki to Unveil Yoshikimono First Collection at Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week| last=Fromets| first=RJ| date=October 2015| publisher=Vents Magazine| access-date=January 18, 2016| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151022052735/http://ventsmagazine.com/2015/10/16/yoshiki-to-unveil-yoshikimono-first-collection-at-mercedes-benz-fashion-week%E2%80%8F/| archivedate=October 22, 2015| df=mdy-all}}</ref> In 2015, the Yoshiki Channel was launched on [[Niconico|Niconico Video]], a Japanese video platform. The channel streams exclusive live shows and distributes links for movies and magazines.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.syncmusic.jp/wordpress/?p=24061| title="YOSHIKI CHANNEL" Opens on Nico Nico Video! | date=August 11, 2015| publisher=Sync Music Japan| access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref>
Yoshiki also has his own [[Hello Kitty]] product line, named ''Yoshikitty''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.barks.jp/news/?id=1000054468|title=YOSHIKI、ハローキティ誕生35周年記念パーティーで新yoshikittyお披露目|date=October 15, 2009|publisher=Barkswlanguage=Japanese|accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.rocketnews24.com/2016/07/20/hello-kitty-teams-up-with-x-japan-to-rock-out-in-yoshiki-kimono/|title=Hello Kitty teams up with X Japan's Yoshiki to rock out in Yoshikimono!|publisher=Rocketnews24|accessdate=April 4, 2017|date=2016-07-20}}</ref>
Yoshiki has partnered with researchers to investigate music as therapy.<ref name=therapy>{{cite web | url = http://oliveventures.com.sg/act/2010/08/14/yoshiki-x-japan-establishes-foundation-of-rock-foundation-for-kids/ | title = Yoshiki Establishes Foundation of Rock Foundation | publisher = Olive Ventures | accessdate = October 24, 2013 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191618/http://oliveventures.com.sg/act/2010/08/14/yoshiki-x-japan-establishes-foundation-of-rock-foundation-for-kids/ | archive-date = October 29, 2013 | dead-url = yes | df = mdy-all }}</ref> Yoshiki also has branded [[MasterCard]] and [[Visa, Inc.|Visa]] credit cards,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://abcnews.go.com/WN/yoshiki-japans-bono-ready-us/story?id=11358722| title=Japan's Bono: Yoshiki Is Ready to Take on the U.S.| last=Harris| first=Dan| date=August 10, 2010| publisher=ABC News| access-date=January 18, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/japanese-music-superstar-yoshiki-to-compose-theme-for-2012-golden-globe-awards-137056618.html| title=Japanese Music Superstar Yoshiki to Compose Theme for 2012 Golden Globe Awards| date=January 10, 2012| access-date=November 4, 2015}}</ref> and is an investor in Green Lord Motors.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.jcarblog.com/2012/10/04/the-tommy-kaira-zz-the-latest-electric-sports-car/| title=The Tommy Kaira ZZ – The latest electric sports car| date=October 4, 2012| publisher=Japanese Car Blog| access-date=January 18, 2016| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160505095845/http://www.jcarblog.com/2012/10/04/the-tommy-kaira-zz-the-latest-electric-sports-car/| archivedate=May 5, 2016| df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.ikegin-c.jp/pdf/frm1301312.pdf| title=Green Lord Motors History| publisher=Green Lord Motors| access-date=January 18, 2016| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305084020/http://www.ikegin-c.jp/pdf/frm1301312.pdf| archivedate=March 5, 2016| df=mdy-all}}</ref>
== Equipment == {{multiple image |direction=vertical |align=right |width=180 |image1=Kawai CR-40A.jpg|caption1=Kawai CR-40A |image2=Kawai custom made piano (Yoshiki).jpg|caption2=Kawai Yoshiki Custom }}
Yoshiki said he considers himself a [[Groove (music)|groove]] drummer.<ref name="drum mag">{{cite journal |url=http://www.drummagazine.com/features/post/yoshiki-japans-revered-drumming-x-port/ |title=Yoshiki: The Japanese Bono's Bonzai Beat |date=January 2011 |last=Lentz |first=Andrew |journal=[[Drum!]] |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20131013193437/http://www.drummagazine.com/features/post/yoshiki-japans-revered-drumming-x-port/|archivedate=October 13, 2013}}</ref> He normally wears a neck brace when playing the drums; as a result of his years of "[[headbanging]]" while drumming, he injured his neck and had to undergo surgery.<ref name="drum mag"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.revolvermag.com/news/interview-x-japan-bandleader-yoshiki-hayashi-talks-next-album-neck-braces-and-more.html|title=Interview: X Japan Bandleader Yoshiki Hayashi Talks Next Album, Neck Braces, And More|date=May 11, 2013|accessdate=April 4, 2017|publisher=[[Revolver (magazine)|Revolver]]}}</ref> In 2015, Yoshiki stated he is more of a songwriter than a drummer.<ref name="drums"/> [[File:Yoshiki playing drums.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Yoshiki's drum kit up close]] [[Tama Drums]] created a custom-made [[Poly (methyl methacrylate)|acrylic]] drum set for Yoshiki to use on stage, the ArtStar series. Yoshiki admitted that the clear acrylic shells are great for appearances, allowing the stage lights to color his drums with varying hues, but are not ideal sound-wise. He has explained that the clear drums are difficult to play because they do not have the usual responsive of wooden shells and are not very durable; as they require much more physical pounding to deliver a good sound and that causes the heads to be essentially ruined after only a single concert.<ref name="drums"/> Yoshiki's live kit uses two {{convert|24|in|adj=on}} [[Bass drum|kick drums]], and centers the 14" [[snare drum]] directly in front of him. He usually works with five [[tom drum]]s: three rack toms with diameters of {{convert|10|in}}, 12" and 13", and two floor toms with diameters of 16" and 18".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tamadrum.co.jp/artist/roster_j10.php?artist_id=369 |title=Yoshiki: Tama Drums |publisher=[[Tama Drums]] |accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref> However, in the studio he uses a custom made [[titanium]] kit with Evans coated heads.<ref name="drums"/>
Yoshiki usually performs on a [[Kawai]] Crystal II Grand Piano CR-40A. Kawai also makes a Yoshiki-model grand piano of traditional wooden design. He has a constant numbness of two fingers on his left hand that he says makes it difficult to play piano.<ref name="drum mag"/> He also suffers from chronic [[Tendinitis|tendonitis]] on his right hand, which may cause him to be unable to play musical instruments in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.en.barks.jp/news/?id=1000005270|title=YOSHIKI of X JAPAN speaks out, "My right hand will not recover"|date=February 5, 2015|accessdate=April 5, 2017|publisher=Barks}}</ref>
